abstract.text: An
object enables and manages communication among all peers in a Multipeer Connectivity session.

inlineContent.text: To set up a session:
Use the
method of the
to create a peer ID that represents the local peer, or retrieve a peer ID that you previously archived (to maintain a stable peer ID over time).
Use the peer ID with the method
to initialize the session object.
Invite peers to join the session using an
object, an
object, or your own peer discovery code. (Sessions currently support up to 8 peers, including the local peer.)
Set up an
object or
object to allow other devices to ask your app to join a session that they create.
If you use one of the framework’s browser objects for peer discovery, when a peer accepts an invitation, the session calls its delegate object’s
method with
as the new state, along with an object that tells you which peer became connected. See Creating a Session for related methods.
If instead you write your own peer discovery code, you are responsible for managing the connection manually. See the
section for more information.
Once you have set up the session, your app can send data to other peers by calling one of the following methods, found in Sending Data and Resources:
sends an
object to the specified peers.
On each recipient device, the delegate object’s
method is called with the data object when the data has been fully received.
sends the contents from an
object to the specified peer. The URL can be either a local file URL or a web URL. The
block is called when the resource is fully received by the recipient peer or when an error occurs during transmission.
This method returns an
object that you can use to cancel the transfer or check the current status of the transfer.
On the recipient device, the session calls its delegate object’s
method when the device begins receiving the resource, and calls its
method when the resource has been fully received or when an error occurs.
creates a connected byte stream (
) that you can use to send data to the specified peer.
On the recipient device, the session calls its delegate object’s
method with an
object that represents the other endpoint of communication.

On both sides, your code must set the stream’s delegate, schedule the stream on a run loop, and open the stream. Your code must also implement stream delegate methods to manage sending and receiving stream data.

Delegate calls occur on a private operation queue. If your app needs to perform an action on a particular run loop or operation queue, its delegate method should explicitly dispatch or schedule that work.
If instead of using the framework’s browser and advertiser objects to perform peer discovery, you decide to write your own peer discovery code (with
or the Bonjour C API, for example), you can manually connect nearby peers into a session. To do this:
Establish a connection from your app to nearby peers, and exchange peer IDs with those peers.
Each peer should serialize its own local
object with
, and the receiving peer should unserialize it with
Do not attempt to construct a peer ID object for a nonlocal peer using
. A peer ID object must be constructed
on the device that it represents
Exchange connection data. After you have obtained the nearby peer’s ID object, call
to obtain a connection data object specific to that nearby peer.
When the completion handler block is called, send the resulting connection data object to that peer.

Each device in the session must perform this step for each nonlocal peer in the session. So if there are four devices in the session, each device must generate a connection data object for each of the other three devices.
When your app receives connection data from another peer, it must call
to add that peer to the session.
Each of the nonlocal peers must also call
with the connection data that it received from your app and other nonlocal peers.
You can also cancel an outstanding connection attempt by calling
. These methods are described in the Managing Peers Manually group.
To leave a session, your app must call
. For more details, see Leaving a Session.

abstract.text: Dismisses a presented view controller, using the same animator that presented it.
Presents another view controller as a sheet.
Dismisses the view controller that was presented modally by the view controller.
Initiates the segue with the specified identifier from the current view controller’s storyboard file.
Notifies the view controller that a segue is about to be performed.
Presents a view controller modally.
Support peer-to-peer connectivity and the discovery of nearby devices.
The

is a convenience class that handles advertising, presents incoming invitations to the user, and handles users’ responses. Use this class to provide a user interface for handling invitations when your app does not require programmatic control over the invitation process.
The
class presents nearby devices to the user and enables the user to invite nearby devices to a session. To use this class in iOS or tvOS, call methods from the underlying
class (
and
for storyboards or
and
for nib-based views) to present and dismiss the view controller. In macOS, use the comparable
methods
and
instead.
Indicates whether a session should use encryption when communicating with nearby peers.
Error codes found in
error domain
objects returned by methods in the Multipeer Connectivity framework.
The
domain constant. If the
value for an
object is equal to
, then the error was produced by the Multipeer Connectivity framework itself, as opposed to a lower-level framework on which it depends.
The
class publishes an advertisement for a specific service that your app provides through the Multipeer Connectivity framework and notifies its delegate about invitations from nearby peers.

Searches (by service type) for services offered by nearby devices using infrastructure Wi-Fi, peer-to-peer Wi-Fi, and Bluetooth (in iOS) or Ethernet (in macOS and tvOS), and provides the ability to easily invite those devices to a Multipeer Connectivity session (
An
object represents a peer in a multipeer session.
Initializes a peer.
An
object enables and manages communication among all peers in a Multipeer Connectivity session.
Cancels an attempt to connect to a peer.
Call this method to connect a peer to the session when using your own service discovery code instead of an
or
object.
An array of all peers that are currently connected to this session.
The delegate object that handles session-related events.
Disconnects the local peer from the session.
A value indicating whether the connection prefers encrypted connections, unencrypted connections, or has no preference.
Creates a Multipeer Connectivity session.
Creates a Multipeer Connectivity session, providing security information.
A local identifier that represents the device on which your app is currently running.
Obtains connection data for the specified peer.
The security identity of the local peer.
Sends a message to nearby peers.
Sends the contents of a URL to a peer.
Opens a byte stream to a nearby peer.
Indicates that the local peer finished receiving a resource from a nearby peer.
Indicates that an
object has been received from a nearby peer.
Called when a nearby peer opens a byte stream connection to the local peer.
Indicates that the local peer began receiving a resource from a nearby peer.
Called when the state of a nearby peer changes.
Indicates whether delivery of data should be guaranteed.
Indicates the current state of a given peer within a session.
The peer is connected to this session.
Constants that define the minimum and maximum number of peers supported in a session.
The error domain for errors specific to Multipeer Connectivity.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
